D. 

Financing Plan 

82. 
The  Government  has  requested  a  program  loan  of  $43.1  million  equivalent  from  ADB's 
Special Funds resources (ADF) and an ADF grant of $16.9 million for the Program to support the 
fiscal  adjustment  necessary  for  Mongolia's  economic  stabilization  program.  The  ADF  loan  will  be 
financed  from  ADB's  Special  Funds  resources,  with  an  annual  interest  rate  of  1.0%  during  the 
grace  period  and  1.5%  thereafter.  It  will  have  a  term  of  24  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8 
years.  The  terms  and  conditions  for  the  loan  and  the  grant  will  be  as  set  forth  in  the  Financing 
Agreement. The Program will be cofinanced by JICA, under a parallel cofinancing arrangement. 
 
83. 
The  collapse  of  the  price  of  copper,  Mongolia’s  major  export  commodity,  has  severely 
disrupted its economy, exacerbating pre-existing balance of payments and fiscal imbalances. The 
IMF  has  estimated  that  only  $2.049  billion  in  external  financing  will  be  available  to  Mongolia 
against  gross  external  financing  requirements  of  $2.486  billion  leaving  a  financing  need  of  $437 
million. Given that this coincides with higher domestic and higher international borrowing costs, the 
Government prefers program loans from development partners to bridge this gap.  
 
84. 
The  IMF  has  estimated  that  Mongolia  will  need  $284  million  of  external  financing  in  2009 
and $153 million in 2010. The IMF stand-by arrangement will provide $139 million in 2009 and $93 
million in 2010. The ADB program support will provide $60 million in 2009, and the Government of 
Japan through JICA will provide $30 million in 2009 and $20 million in 2010. The World Bank will 
provide  $40  million  in  200933 and  $20  million  in  2010.  These  combined  disbursements  will  cover 
most of the financing shortfall, with a gap of $15 million in 2009 and $20 million in 2010 which the 
Government  envisages  covering  through  assistance  from  other  donors.  The  cofinancing  effort  by 
ADB,  JICA  and  World  Bank  addresses  macroeconomic  and  social  protection  issues.  The 
development coordination matrix illustrates the specific reforms under each of the above financiers 
(Appendix  4).  Counterpart  funds  generated  from  the  proceeds  of  the  Program  will  be  used  for 
budget support in meeting Government expenditures for social sectors. The Program amount has 
taken  into  account  the  IMF's  estimated  fiscal  gap  and  partners'  contributions  to  fill  the  gap.  The 
amended  budget  passed  in  March  2009  was  conditional  on  commitments  made  by  development 
agencies  to  fill  the  fiscal  gap.  This amended  budget  minimized  cuts  in  social sector  budgets and 
protected current expenditures at the expense of capital expenditures. Budget cuts for social sector 
ministries—e.g.,  MSWL  (19%),  MOH  (10%),  and  MOECS  (10.8%)—were  generally  less  drastic 
than  cuts  for  other  ministries—e.g.,  MRTCUD  (39.75%),  Ministry  of  Fuel  and  Energy  (34.79%). 
Further budget cuts are planned for June 2009, and these will affect the social sectors, if the fiscal 
gap cannot be entirely closed.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

85. 
Program Management. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will be the Executing Agency (EA) 
and will assume overall responsibility for the implementation of the Program. The MSWL, the MOH, 
the  MOECS,  the  MRTCUD,  and  the  Ulaanbaatar  Municipal  Office  will  be  the  implementing 
agencies.  Each  implementing  agency  will  assume  responsibility  for  the  implementation  of  the 
policy measures related to its areas of responsibilities.  
 
86. 
In its capacity as the EA, MOF will establish the Program Steering Committee (PSC) to be 
chaired  by  the  state  secretary  of  the  MOF.  The  members  of  the  PSC  will  be  the  senior 
representatives  of  the  implementing  agencies.  The  PSC  will  (i)  monitor  the  Program,  and  (ii) 
provide policy and strategic guidance.  
 
The  MOF  will  also  establish  a  program  support  unit  (PSU)  that  will  (i)  serve  as  the 
87. 
secretariat of the PSC; (ii) manage the implementation of the Program, including liaising with the 
various implementation agencies to ensure proper and timely achievement, adoption, compliance 
with, and implementation of the policy measures; and (iii) prepare and submit necessary reports, 
including  periodic  progress  reports,  to  ADB.  The  MOF  will  appoint  one  of  its  staff  members  from 
the  Department  of  Development  Financing  and  Cooperation  to  head  the  PSU.  A  deputy  will  be 
recruited  externally  through  a  competitive  process  to  be  financed  through  an  accompanying  TA. 
The  deputy  will  be  assisted  by  an  administrative  assistant,  hired  under  the  accompanying  TA,  to 
facilitate coordination and administration of the TA inputs and reporting. The MOF will also allocate 
appropriate office space and facilities to ensure an effective and efficient PSU. Each implementing 
agency will appoint a staff member to act as its program focal point and coordinate with the head of 
the PSU. 
 
88. 
Implementation Period. The implementation period is from April 2009 to December 2010. 
The loan closing date will be 31 December 2010. The duration of the Program, which has started in 
April 2009, will extend up to December 2010 (12 months after the planned release of the second 
tranche) for the following reasons: (i) the JICA second tranche release is in April 2010, (ii) to allow 
for better monitoring of the execution of the 2010 budget and avoid budget amendments that would 
counter  reforms  that  have  already  been  passed,  and  (iii)  to  make  prolonged  and  intense  policy 
dialogue more likely than could be achieved through the TA.

the  provisions  of  ADB’s

Recipient. The proceeds of the loan and the grant will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of imports produced in, and procured from, ADB’s member 
countries, other than those specified in the list of ineligible items (Appendix 5) and imports financed 
by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources  and  from  countries  that  are  not  ADB  members.  The

ADB’s projected disbursements under the loan and the grant in a given period; and (ii) the loan and 
the grant proceeds will be used as agreed in a manner satisfactory to ADB. The loan and the grant 
proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  line  with  the  simplified  disbursement  procedures  for  program  loans 
and  the  Loan  Disbursement  Handbook  (January  2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  loan

Program  Performance  Management  System.  The  MOF,  through  the  PSU,  will  be

Anticorruption  Policy.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was 
explained  to  and  discussed  with  the  Government  and  MOF.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to 
good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly

Program. To support these efforts, relevant provisions of the Anticorruption Policy are included in 
the loan and grant regulations. In particular, all contracts financed by ADB in connection with the 
Program  and  TA  shall  include  provisions  specifying  the  right  of  ADB  to  audit  and  examine  the

In  2008,  a  sector  risk  assessment34 was  carried  out  for  Mongolia  for  national  systems  as 
94. 
well  as  the  education  and  urban  transport  sectors  in  the  areas  of  public  finance  management, 

                                                 
34 The risk assessment was carried out following the 2008 guidelines of the Governance and Anti-Corruption Action Plan 

(GACAP II). 

 

 21        

procurement,  and  anticorruption.  This  found  that  Mongolia's  legal,  policy,  and  institutional 
frameworks  remain  generally  inadequate  to  mitigate  or  obviate  risk  in  national  and  sectoral 
systems.  Significant  vulnerabilities  and  risk  in  public  finance  management  stem  from  the 
Government’s limited capacity to implement development policies and reform, and to ensure that 
all  elements,  notably  budget  formulation,  allocation,  and  execution  are  consistent  with  policy 
priorities.  There  is  also  evidence  that  interventionist  central  planning,  and  political  interference 
introduces additional vulnerability and risk that must be mitigated. Procurement risks include a lack 
of  capacity,  knowledge,  and  adequate  training  to  equip  professional  procurement  officers  to 
dispatch  their  duties  and  responsibilities  fairly  and  transparently.  Political  interference,  conflict  of 
interest, and corruption are manifest within national and sectoral procurement systems. Corruption 
is  pervasive,  and  additional  support  to  the  Government  of  Mongolia,  and  to  the  Independent 
Authority Against Corruption is required to strengthen institutional capacity and effectiveness.35 
 
The  proposed  Program  will  provide  funding  to  reduce  the  fiscal  gap  and  require  policy 
95. 
actions  from  the  MSWL,  the  MOH,  the  MOECS,  the  MRTCUD,  and  the  Ulaanbaatar  City

national  systems  (para.  94)  identified  risks  related  to  public  finance  management  and  corruption, 
which are applicable to the present Program. Reforms to reduce the risk of corruption and improve 
public  financial  and  procurement  systems  are  underway  by  the  Government.  Donors,  including 
ADB  and  the  World  Bank  will  help  to  put  mitigation  measures  in  place  to  address  the  identified

V. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

97. 
Objectives. The TA aims to support the implementation and coordination of policy reforms 
under  the  Program.  Specifically,  it  will  (i)  support  policy  reforms  on  targeting  assistance  and 
improving  social  sector  efficiency,  (ii)  strengthen  statistical  analysis  and  data  collection,  (iii)  build 
capacity  for  the  management  of  an  intersectoral  national  database  of  beneficiaries  of  social 
assistance and other government subsidies, (iv) develop consensus on targeting social assistance 
with national and local government officials and the public, and (v) develop environment and social 
safeguard capacity for urban development stakeholders in Ulaanbaatar. 

                                                 
35 The main proposed reforms to improve public financial  systems are: (i) strengthening the public financing framework 
by  better  aligning  policy  priorities  with  budgeting  and  anchoring  the  budget  to  clear  fiscal  rules,  (ii)  allowing  public 
access to budget documents, (iii) amending the budget process to limit the scope for undue external interference, and 
(iv) strengthening the financial management capacity of all line ministries. To improve procurement systems, two main 
measures are called for: (i) facilitating the engagement of the public and civil society in procurement monitoring, and 
(ii)  strengthening  the  Independent  Authority  Against  Corruption.  Proposed  reforms  to  reduce  the  risk  of  corruption 
include:  (i)  strengthening  the  legislative  and  institutional  framework,  including  the  Anti-Corruption  Law  to  criminalize 
private  sector  corruption,  illicit  enrichment,  criminal  conflict  of  interest,  and  election-related  offenses;  and  (ii) 
implementing anticorruption plans and codes of ethical conduct in ministries and agencies. 

36 The  World  Bank  aims  to  assist  the  Government  in  (i)  improving  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  governance 
processes in the management of public finances, (ii) promoting transparency and accountability in the performance of 
public  sector  functions,  and  (iii)  fostering  the  investment  climate  in  Mongolia.  ADB's  objective  is  to  mitigate 
procurement  and  corruption  risks  in  the  education  sector  in  Mongolia  through  carrying  out  procurement  and 
anticorruption priority  interventions at the sectoral level and enhance institutional and  staff capacity in the Ministry  of 
Education, Culture and Science. 

 

 

 22       

 
A. 

Components and Outputs 

98. 
The TA will help ensure that reform targets are met and that the foundations for systemic 
change  across  sectors  are  built,  promoting  efficiency,  the  prioritization  of  the  poor,  and  the 
provision  of  targeted  social  assistance.  The  TA  will  help  to  build  firm  foundations  for  change 
through strategic capacity development and will develop a consensus-building program on the role 
of social assistance and the classification of recipients.  
 
Sector  Policy  Reform  Coordination  and  Implementation  Support. The TA will support 
99. 
the Government and MOF to coordinate the policy reforms across the sectors as envisaged in the 
policy  matrix.  A  national  consultant  will  work  in  the  PSU  and  help  the  MOF  to  manage 
implementation and coordination of the Program, prepare and submit reports for the Government 
and  ADB,  support  ADB  missions,  liaise  with  the  appointed  focal  points  and  working  groups  from 
each  ministry,  and  coordinate  the  consultant  inputs  from  the  other  components  of  the  TA.  The 
national  consultant  will  be  the  deputy  of  the  head  of  the  PSU  and  will  be  assisted  by  an 
administrative assistant. 
 
100.  Sector-Specific  Capacity  Development  to  Support  Targeting.  The  TA  will  support 
capacity  building  for  targeting  within  the  MOH  and  the  MOECS  by  (i)  supporting  the  working 
groups  in  each  ministry  as  they  decide  how  to  integrate  PMT  and  other  targeting  methodologies 
into their assistance strategies, (ii) providing assistance in developing monitoring methodologies for 
the  targeted  assistance,  and  (iii)  providing  guidelines  and  training  for  the  implementation  of  PMT 
and other targeting methods in the programs outlined in the policy matrix.  
 
101.  NSO  Capacity  Development  in  Statistical  Analysis  and  Data  Gathering.  An  effective 
PMT  is  dependent  on  reliable  data  on  poverty  levels  and  on  the  capacity  to  identify  and  analyze 
new  vulnerable  populations  over  time.  The  TA  will  help  the  NSO  to  train  staff  in  targeting 
methodologies  (such  as  PMT  and  poverty  mapping),  data  collection,  processing,  and  analysis  to 
support  ministries  seeking  to  target  their  benefits  at  the  poor.  This  assistance  will  support  the 
reforms  under  the  Program  and  provide  a  foundation  for  the  sustainable  use  of  PMT  and  other 
targeting methodologies across different sectors. 
 
Intersectoral  Beneficiaries  Database.  The  beneficiaries  identified  by  the  PMT  will  form 
102. 
the basis for a national database of the poor, which can be used by sectors and programs across 
the  country.  There  is  a  risk  that,  by  accumulating  different  types  of  transfers,  a  household  might 
rise  above  the  poverty  threshold  defined  by  the  PMT,  making  an  intersectoral  database  of 
beneficiaries  and  transfers  essential.  Therefore,  the  TA  will  support  the  development  and 
management  of  an  intersectoral  database  that  links  information  on  benefits  and  beneficiaries, 
allows  for  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  sector  programs,  and  avoids  the  overaccumulation  of 
benefits in any given household.  
 
103.  Consensus  Building  on  Reforming  Social  Assistance. Targeted social assistance has 
been  implemented  successfully  in  Mongolia  before,  but  new  government  revenues  encouraged 
politicians  to  promote  universal  access.  Reluctance  to  change  from  universal  access  is  therefore 
an important risk that the Program must address. The TA will support a government advocacy and 
public awareness program for (i) parliamentarians, (ii) civil society, and (iii) the public. The program 
will focus on building a consensus on social assistance targeting through workshops and outreach 
activities that will focus on (i) the benefits of targeting, (ii) the need for fiscal sustainability, (iii) the 
mechanics of identification, and (iv) grievance mechanisms. Building understanding and trust in the 
system from the ground up to decision makers will help ensure that reforms are adhered to in the 
future. 
 

 

 23        

104.  Developing  Environment  and  Social  Safeguards  Capacity 
for  Ulaanbaatar 
Stakeholders.  The  revision  of  the  Ulaanbaatar  master  plan  and  capacity  development  in  urban 
development strategies is the focus of two of the proposed policy reforms under the Program. To 
address the concerns of the poor living in ger areas, it is essential that adequate capacity be built 
in  safeguards  implementation  and  management  of  consultation  processes.  The  TA37 will  support 
strategic capacity building in environment and social safeguards for Ulaanbaatar.  
 
B. 

Cost Estimates and Implementation Arrangements 

105.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan. The total cost of the TA is estimated at $800,000. It 
will be financed on a grant basis from the TA Special Fund-IV in the amount of $700,000. The TA 
will  finance  consulting  services;  equipment  and  software;  surveys;  workshops  and  training; 
information,  education,  and  communication  activities;  contingencies;  and  miscellaneous 
administration  and  support  costs.  The  Government  will  finance  the  balance  of  the  local  currency 
cost, equivalent to $100,000, through the provision of counterpart staff, office facilities, and other 
support services. The detailed cost estimates, financing plan and outline terms of reference are in 
Supplementary Appendix F. 
 
106. 
Implementation  Arrangements.  The  MOF  will  be  the  EA  for  the  Program  and  the  TA, 
which  will  have  similar  organization  structures.  The  PSU  for  the  Program  will  coordinate  the 
activities and outputs of the TA and provide oversight and guidance. The TA grant is intended to 
facilitate  program  reforms  and  will  therefore  be  integrated  with  program  implementation.  The 
Government will integrate common activities and processes among ADB-supported programs and 
projects including the FNSWPP, Third Health Sector Development Project, and Education for the 
Poor, thereby improving the efficiency of implementation, especially in procurement and consultant 
selection. The TA will be implemented over 2 years and will be completed by June 2011, 6 months 
after completion of the Program (December 2010).  
  
107.  Procurement and Consultant Selection. All equipment and materials will be procured by 
the MOF in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). 
Ownership  will  be  transferred  to  the  Government  after  completion  of  the  TA.  The  equipment  and 
materials  procured  will  include  computers,  software,  printers,  and  other  equipment  necessary  for 
the  implementation  of  TA  activities.  Consultants  will  be  recruited  under  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the 
Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) for the recruitment of international and 
national consultants. ADB will recruit the consultants on an individual basis. Each TA component 
will require consulting services of up to three individual consultants. A total of 19 person-months of 
international  consultants  (6  consultants)  and  46  person-months  of  national  consultants  (7 
consultants) will be needed to support TA activities. 
 
108.  Disbursement  and  Reporting.  The  TA  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  line  with  ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2008). Direct payment procedures will be used to 
pay  for  consulting  services.  An  advance  payment  facility  for  the  TA  will  be  established  with  the 
MOF for workshops, training expenditures, and procurement of the equipment. The MOF is familiar 
with  ADB  procedures  and  has  adequate  financial  management  capacity  to  handle  the  advance 
payment  facility.  Costed  activity  proposals,  approved  by  the  MOF,  will  be  submitted  to  ADB  for 
approval.  The  reporting  and  review  of  the  TA  will  be  combined  with  that  of  the  Program  and  will 
follow the procedures laid down for the Program. The quarterly, annual, and TA completion reports, 
included with the reports on the Program, will include a summary financial report on the TA.

A. 

Benefits 

VI. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS AND RISKS 

109.  Beneficiaries  and  Fiscal  Sustainability.  By  strengthening  and  reforming  social  welfare 
systems, and especially by improving targeting, the Program will help to improve the performance 
and fiscal sustainability of the Government. By converting the CMP to a targeted benefit, the IMF 
estimates that MNT61,033 million could be saved. The elimination of exclusion and inclusion errors 
will  result  in  social  assistance  reaching  945,000  beneficiaries,  a  reduction  of  355,000  from  the 
1,300,000 receiving social assistance in 2008.38 By targeting other social benefits more efficiently, 
another MNT12,206 million could be saved.39 With these savings, equivalent to 1.16% of GDP in 
2009, the Government could increase benefit levels for the poorest households without creating an 
unsustainable fiscal burden. The additional benefit will lift about 40,000 people above the poverty 
line.  Fiscal  sustainability  will  provide  a  basis  for  sound  economic  recovery,  and  thereby  diminish 
the burden on the state to provide for the unemployed and other groups made vulnerable by the 
financial crisis. The poor will benefit, as they will receive at least the same level of CMP benefit as 
in 2008. The Government will benefit from the stronger public finances and the MSWL will benefit 
from  a  streamlined  and  targeted  system.  Non-poor  will  be  dropped  as  beneficiaries.  As  eligibility 
will be based on poverty level and the overall benefit amount is not substantial, the loss of income 
for these stakeholders will not have a significant impact on their consumption level. In addition, it is 
estimated that there will be (i) 1,550,000 drug discount beneficiaries; (ii) 303,000 people who are 
currently  uninsured  who  will  benefit  from  improved  targeting  of  health  insurance  subsidies;  (iii) 
83,000  children  under  2  years  of  age  who  will  benefit  from  micronutrient  supplementation;  (iv) 
630,000  poor  who  will  benefit  from  the  medicard  program;  and  (v)  100,000  secondary  school 
students  who  will  receive  textbook  subsidies.  Supplementary  Appendix  G  contains  additional 
estimates of program beneficiaries by policy reform. 
 
110.  Consolidation  of  Welfare  Benefit. The Program will significantly improve the institutional 
capacity  of  the  Government  to  consolidate  and  target  social  welfare  benefits.  The  cabinet-level 
working  group  and  other  working  groups  at  ministerial  level  will  be  key  to  this.  The  Program  will 
improve the policy framework for consolidating social transfers and will therefore complement the 
objectives of the Food and Nutrition Social Welfare Project to rationalize social welfare.  
 
111.  Paving  the  Way  for  Associated  Projects. The policy measures of the Program that are 
focused on targeting social welfare benefits will pave the way for associated projects in health (the 
medicard  program  and  household  micronutrients)  (footnote  29)  and  in  education  (school 
textbooks).40 These  projects  will  help  very  poor  households  to  meet  their  basic  needs  during  the 
financial crisis.  The  Program  will  also  build  on the  FNSWPP  by  extending  the  PMT  to  the  health 
and education sectors so that these benefits are well targeted. 
 
112.  Harmonization  of  Development  Efforts.  The  Program’s  efforts  to  harmonize  its 
interventions  with  other  international  efforts  (e.g.,  those  of  the  IMF,  JICA,  UNDP,  and  the  World 
Bank), and the Government’s broader plans and programs (e.g., social welfare reform), will help to 
prevent duplication of effort and ensure the efficiency of social welfare programs and targeting in 
health and education.

 25        

 
Improved  Government  Capacity.  The  reform  measures  will  improve  the  capacity  of  the 
113. 
Government to deliver consolidated and targeted safety welfare assistance. The accompanying TA 
will  pave  the  way  for  a  nationwide  PMT,  the  results  of  which  will  enable  the  Government  to 
establish and manage a unified social security database that serves the needs of several sectors. 
In urban planning, capacity building will focus on ensuring that expertise is available to build social 
and environmental safeguards into planning exercises. 
 
B. 

Impacts 

114. 
Institutional  Impact.  Government  institutions,  particularly  the  MSWL,  the  MOH,  and  the 
MOECS, will be better able to reform themselves and deliver social welfare services. The unified 
database  will  enable  different  sectors  to  target  their  services  to  meet  the  basic  needs  of  the 
population. 
 
115.  Poverty Reduction. Mongolia’s social welfare system has had a limited impact on poverty 
reduction  because  of  its  poor  targeting.  Under  the  Program,  benefits  will  be  consolidated  and 
targeting  will  be  greatly  improved,  resulting  in  significant  cost  savings.  This  will  create  an 
opportunity to increase the size of key benefits benefiting households in the lowest quintile, many 
of  whom  depend  on  such  benefits.  Subsidized  essential  drugs  will  be  made  available  in  greater 
measure  in  PHC  and  outpatient  facilities.  Out-of-pocket  expenses  will  decline  and  fewer  poor 
patients  will  require  hospitalization.  Malnourished  children  will  receive  critical  micronutrients  at 
home. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 7, and the poverty and 
social assessment is in Supplementary Appendix H. 
 
116.  Gender  Benefits.  These  social  welfare  reforms  will  have  consequences  for  virtually  all 
citizens,  male  and  female.  Access  to  health  services  and  education  are  particularly  gendered  in 
Mongolia.  More  women  than  men  use  primary  health  care facilities,  and  girls  have  higher  school 
and  tertiary  education  enrollment  than  boys.  Special  efforts  will  be  made  to  ensure  that  these 
disparities  are  addressed  in  the  reform  and  targeting  programs.  A  gender  action  plan  has  been 
prepared  to  maximize  the  opportunities  for  gender  impact  in  design  and  implementation  and  to 
provide  adequate  and  sex-disaggregated  data  for  monitoring  and  evaluating  the  Program 
(Appendix 8). 
 
117.  Economic  and  Financial  Impacts.  The  Program  will  provide  direct  budgetary  support  to 
the Government. The nature of the Program limits the scope for quantitative economic analysis but 
quantitative  and  qualitative  assessments  of  specific  measures  were  undertaken.  Supplementary 
Appendix  I  provides  the  economic  and  financial  analysis  of  the  Program,  including  the  projected 
reduction  in  (i)  the  Government's  fiscal  burden  and  (ii)  out-of-pocket  expenses  for  the  poorest 
segment of the population. 
 
118.  The social protection expenditure of the State can be divided into: (i) pensions and benefits 
(e.g.  old  age,  disability,  military,  accident  pensions,  and  sickness,  funeral,  and  unemployment 
benefits); and (ii) social welfare expenses (e.g. allowances for children under 18 years, pregnancy 
and  maternity  leave,  newly  weds,  newborns,  school  lunches,  and  textbooks).  Very  few  savings 
would be possible by reducing expenditure in the first category, as these pensions and benefits are 
well  established  and  have  statutory  protection.  However,  the  economic  analysis  illustrates  that 
proxy  means  testing  could  lead  to  significant  savings  in  the  second  category  by  targeting  social 
welfare benefits at people living below the poverty line (35% of the population). If the CMP, which 
makes  up  more  than  half  the  expenditure  in  this  category,  was  focused  on  these  households, 
MNT69,000 million could be saved from the original 2009 budget. By targeting other social benefits 
in  the  same  way  (including  reducing  duplication  of  benefits),  the  IMF  estimates  that  another 
MNT12,206 million could be saved. 

 

 26       

 
119.  The  net  effects  of  the  five  interventions  in  the  health  sector  will  be  to  improve  the  health 
outcomes  of  the  poor  by  reducing  their  out-of-pocket  costs  and  improving  their  access  to  health 
services during the crisis and after. According to the 2007–2008 household socioeconomic survey, 
people  in  the  poorest  quintile  spend  an  average  of  MNT1,001  per  month,  or  2%  of  their  total 
consumption,  on  health  care.  If  such  out-of-pocket  expenses  were  to  be  eliminated  for  the 
expected duration of the financial crisis, the net benefit would be MNT13.1 billion (at 2009 prices).  
 
C. 

Social Safeguards 

120.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement. The Program is designed to minimize the effects of 
the financial crisis on the most vulnerable segment of the population through the implementation of 
policy measures in the social welfare, health, and education sector. These activities will not trigger 
any  resettlement  issues.  Capacity  development  for  social  safeguards,  including  in  the  area  of 
resettlement and indigenous people, will increase consideration of these issues in the revision of 
the  Ulaanbaatar  master  plan  and  the  incorporation  of  safeguard  measures  into  future  urban 
infrastructure projects.  
 
121.  Ethnic  Minority  Issues.  The  Program  will  implement  policy  measures  to  ensure  the 
provision  of  essential  basic  services  to  the  poorest  and  most  vulnerable.  The  poverty  and  social 
assessment has confirmed that the reforms will be applied nationally and no negative impacts on 
indigenous peoples will occur. 
 
D. 

Environmental Aspects 

122.  The Program is classified as category C in line with ADB’s Environmental Policy (2002). It is 
focused  on  minimizing  the  effects  of  the  financial  crisis  on  the  most  vulnerable  segment  of  the 
population. Health, education, and broader social welfare policy measures will have positive effects 
on  the  beneficiary  population  by  increasing  their  access  to  essential  basic  services  during  the 
financial  crisis  and  in  the  longer  term.  Any  concerns  about  negative  environmental  impacts  from 
the increased use of medical services, including medication that will become more readily available 
as  a  result  of  the  program,  are  negligible.  Negative  environmental  impacts  arising  from 
interventions  in  the  education  sector  are  also  negligible.  The  policy  measures  to  improve  the 
professional  expertise  in  environmental  and  social  safeguards  of  the  working  group  revising  the 
Ulaanbaatar  master  plan  will  ensure  environmental  issues  are  increasingly  considered,  thereby 
minimizing  the  environmental  impact  of  future  improvements  to  essential  basic  services  in 
Ulaanbaatar,  particularly  in  the  ger  areas.  Since  the  Program  is  category  C,  there  is  no  need  to 
conduct either an initial environmental examination or a strategic environmental assessment for the 
proposed Program. The environmental analysis is in Supplementary Appendix J. 
 
E. 

Risks 

123.  High Expectations. The universalization of previously targeted welfare benefits was based 
on promises made during election campaigns. From July 2006, at a time of rapid economic growth, 
all  households  with  children  under  18  years  became  accustomed  to  receiving  cash  grants.  The 
Government may face opposition to a plan to revert to targeted child benefits. There is a lack of a 
clear  consensus  on  this  issue in  the  government.  Promises  of  large  unconditional  cash  grants  of 
over MNT1 million for each Mongolian made by candidates in the recently concluded presidential 
elections  can  only  increase  public  opposition  to  targeted  conditional  transfers.  This  risk  will  be 
mitigated  through  concerted  policy  dialogue  with  other  donors  and  an  intense  education  and 
consensus-building  initiative  targeting  members  of  parliament,  the  media,  civil  servants,  and  the 
public. This will be done through TA provided to the Program. 
 

 

 27        

124.  Deepening  Macroeconomic  Instability.  If  the  Government  is  unable  to  implement  the 
economic stabilization program agreed with the IMF or if the global economy recovers slowly, the 
macroeconomic  situation  will  deteriorate,  which  will  have  negative  implications  for  the  social 
sectors. This risk will be mitigated by continuous high-level policy dialogue by ADB and other major 
donors. 
 
125.  Overoptimistic  Expectations  of  Recovery.  The  price  of  copper  is  volatile.  Sudden 
increases  (such  as  that  in  mid-April  2009)  can  easily  be  misinterpreted  as  a  sign  of  economic 
recovery. There is a risk that targeting may be opposed in the expectation that small increases in 
minerals prices will be sustained and that the economy will recover. This risk will be mitigated by 
advocacy work through the accompanying TA project to raise awareness among parliamentarians 
of the need for targeting to maintain long-term fiscal stability and savings. The policy dialogue that 
is  part  of  the  quarterly  macro  assessment  under  the  IMF  stand-by  arrangement  will  also  help  to 
maintain the commitment of the Government to reform targeting. 
 
126.  Delays in Establishing the National Database of Poor Households. It will take time for 
the  new  PMT  national  database  to  function  efficiently.  This  may  increase  the  reluctance  of  the 
MOECS,  the  MOH,  and  the  MSWL  to  adopt  PMT.  It  may  also  increase  the  reluctance  of  the 
Parliament to approve a comprehensive overhaul of the social welfare system and to introduce and 
reform  targeting  measures  in  the  health,  health  insurance,  and  education  sectors.  A  delay  in 
establishing the database may also postpone implementation of the medicard program. A transition 
strategy is therefore needed, which will help to improve targeting (e.g. through creation of a list of 
people  who  do  not  need  social  assistance)  until  the  PMT  and  the  national  database  become 
available.  The  transition  strategy  will  be  part  of  the  plan  to  reform  social  welfare.  The 
accompanying  TA  and  the  ongoing  Food  and  Nutrition  Social  Welfare  Project  will  help  to 
accelerate  the  development  of  the  PMT  by  field-testing  it,  collecting  information  on  households, 
and designing the national database. 
 
F. 

Assumptions  

127.  Global  Economy  Recovers  in  the  Medium  Term. The Program is designed to pave the 
way  for  programs  to  meet  the  basic  needs  of  the  poor,  including  access  to  health  care, 
micronutrients,  and  schooling.  It  will  also  set  fundamental  reforms  and  planning  processes  in 
motion that will, in the medium to long term, profoundly restructure the way social welfare benefits 
are provided. A key assumption is that the economy will start to recover in the medium term and, 
as a result, the fiscal gains from improved targeting will not be undermined by further increases in 
the absolute number of poor. It is also assumed that many of the transient poor, made up mostly of 
unemployed workers, will find employment as the economy  recovers and will therefore no longer 
require social welfare benefits.  
 
128.  National Database System Works Efficiently. It is assumed that the new PMT system will 
lay the foundation for a national registration system that can be managed with sufficient expertise 
and efficiency to detect significant variations in household socioeconomic status. When combined 
with  transparent  and  participatory  grievance  and  appeal  mechanisms  at  the  local  level,  this  will 
minimize  inclusion  and  exclusion  errors.  It  is  assumed  that,  at  the  national  level,  there  will  be 
sufficient  budgetary  support  and  capacity  to  avoid  the  inclusion  and  exclusion  errors  that  are 
otherwise likely to occur in a rapidly changing economy.

Specific Assurances 

VII. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 

129. 
assurances, which will be incorporated in the legal documents. The Government will:  
 
(i) 

use  the  counterpart  funds  to  (a)  finance  expenditures  for  the  Government’s  general 
development purposes, and (b) support the adjustment costs of reforms to be initiated and 
implemented under the Program; 
ensure (a) proper and timely achievement, adoption, compliance, and implementation of the 
objectives,  policies  and  actions  as  set  forth  in  the  Development  Policy  Letter  and  the 
accompanying policy matrix; and (b) that the policies adopted and the actions taken as set 
forth in the Development Policy Letter and the accompanying policy matrix will continue to 
be in full force and effect for the duration of the Program period and subsequently; 
keep ADB informed of, and the Government and ADB will from time to time exchange views 
on,  sector  issues  and  policy  reforms  that  may  be  considered  necessary  or  desirable, 
including  the  progress  made  in  carrying  out  policies  and  actions  as  set  forth  in  the 
Development Policy Letter and the accompanying policy matrix; 
promptly discuss with ADB problems and constraints encountered during implementation of 
the  Program  and  appropriate  measures  to  overcome  or  mitigate  such  problems  and 
constraints; 
keep  ADB  informed  of  policy  discussions  with  other  multilateral  or  bilateral  agencies  that 
have  implications  for  the  implementation  of  the  Program,  and  will  provide  ADB  with  an 
opportunity  to  comment  on  any  resulting  policy  proposals.  The  Government  will  consider 
ADB’s views before finalizing and implementing any such proposals; 
take necessary measures to ensure certain minimum amount of expenditures are allocated 
within  the  state  budget  to  ensure  that  (a)  the  capitation  rates  in  2010  for  family  group 
practices and soum health centers, at minimum, remain equal to its 2008 level; and (b) the 
benefit  level  of  the  CMP  per  child  in  2010  for  the  lowest  socio-economic  quintile,  at 
minimum, remains equal to its 2008 level;41 
ensure  that  the  Gender  Action  Plan  agreed  under  the  Program  will  be  implemented  in  a 
timely manner; and  
ensure  that  guidelines  and  capacity  building  materials  on  environmental  and  social 
safeguard  policies  as  they  related  to  the  urban  master  plan  and  improvement  of  living 
conditions in ger areas will be prepared in compliance with (a) ADB's Environmental Policy 
(2002),  (b)  ADB's  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  (1995),  and  (c)  ADB's  Policy  on

A. 

Meeting Basic Needs 

SECTOR ANALYSIS

the  1997  Asian 

The Social Sectors Support Program (the Program) is designed to promote reforms that 
1. 
will pave the way for pro-poor programs and projects that help to meet the basic needs of the 
poor  during  and  beyond  the  current  financial  crisis.  The  crisis  is  likely  to  worsen  poverty. 
Lessons 
increased 
unemployment  and  poverty,  resulting  in  declines  in  education  and  health  outcomes.  Cash 
transfers  played  a  critical  role  in  alleviating  poverty  in  the  wake  of  the  1997  crisis,  while 
education,  nutrition,  and  healthcare  programs  helped  contain  the  emergence  of  long-term 
adverse effects.1  
 
2. 
A  World  Bank  review  of  financial  crises  around  the  world  supports  these  findings  and 
points to the importance of protecting selected social expenditures during economic downturns, 
particularly  those  relating  to  nutrition  and  health  outcomes.  Conditional  cash  transfers  are  an 
effective  way  to  maintain  school  attendance  and  health  care  and  can  be  effectively  linked  to 
self-targeting  workfare  programs  such  as  public  works  programs.  Where  basic  needs  are  met 
through target programs, the World Bank review notes that political support is critical.2  
 
A financial crisis can be a catalyst for making government’s social support mechanisms 
3. 
more effective. Because the crisis imposes fiscal constraints on expenditure, difficult decisions 
have  to  be  made.  These  usually  entail  prioritizing  expenditures  and  building  efficiency  into 
existing systems. The reforms need not be short term. They can pave the way for more effective 
long-term measures that meet the basic needs of the poor. In this respect, better targeting can 
play  a  key  role  in  improving  fiscal  sustainability  while  increasing  benefits  to  the  poorest 
segments of society.  
 
Food, health, education, employment, and basic living conditions are key basic needs to 
4. 
be protected during crises, especially for the poor. While governmental responsibilities to meet 
citizens' basic needs are divided among ministries, there is a vital common theme among them 
that the Program addresses: targeting resources to those most in need. To this end, there is a 
need  to  work  closely  with  the  Government  to  design,  test,  and  implement  a  nationwide  proxy 
means test (PMT). The outcome of this exercise will be a powerful targeting tool available to all 
social  sector  agencies.  This  appendix  summarizes  the  issues  facing  the  three  key  ministries 
mandated to provide for the basic needs of the poor—the Ministry of Social Welfare and Labor, 
the  Ministry  of  Health,  and  the  Ministry  of  Education,  Culture  and  Science—in  view  of  the 
significant  budget  cuts  they  now  face.  It  discusses  the  issues  facing  the  urban  poor  and  their 
living conditions in light of the financial crisis and budget reductions. 
 
B. 

Social Assistance 

5. 
General  Background.  Prior  to  Mongolia's  transition  into  a  market  economy,  the  state 
guaranteed all Mongolians of working age a job for life, living quarters, and upon retirement, a 
pension. With the transition, these traditional state benefits fell away. Between 1990 and 1993, 
Mongolia suffered a recession that caused massive layoffs in state enterprises. As the share of 
workers  with  no  social  security  benefits  increased,  the  need  grew  for  a  social  safety  net  to 
                                                 
1  UNICEF. 2008. Economic Crisis and Its Social Impact: Lessons from the 1997 Asian Economic Crisis. New York 

(prepared for UNICEF conference in Singapore, 6–7 January 2009).  

2  World Bank Development Research Group. 2008. Lessons from World Bank Research on Financial Crises. Policy 

Research Working Paper 4779. Washington, DC. 

 

 Appendix 2       35 

protect poor workers and their families. The Government's response was to establish an array of 
benefits  of  three  main  types:  (i)  welfare  pensions  for  the  elderly  and  those  with  permanent 
disabilities;  (ii)  child-related  allowances,  including  prenatal,  infant,  and  child  care  and  benefits 
for large families, etc.; and (iii) social welfare services and concessions for the poor, disabled, 
elderly, war veterans, and heroes.3   
 
6. 
While  the  new  system  helped  to  carry  many  Mongolian  households  through  difficult 
times, it was recognized as being too complex and having many redundancies. Further, many 
benefits did not target poverty and the targeting mechanisms that did exist were subjective and 
open  to  misuse.  The  World  Bank  estimates  that  as  much  as  70%  of  beneficiary  households 
were not poor, and that 40% of poor households—and 25% of the poorest households—did not 
receive any assistance.  
 
7. 
Due to poor targeting and small benefit sizes, the impact on poverty of the post-transition 
system  was  considered  to  be  relatively  small. 4  The  lack  of  proper  targeting  caused  large 
inclusion and exclusion errors and placed a serious fiscal burden on the state. A key reason for 
introducing  poor  targeting  is  that  the  post-transition  system  was  based  on  broad  official 
definitions of vulnerability, with over 20 defined categories of beneficiaries, including all children 
under  16,  elderly  people,  mothers  with  newborns,  single  parents,  and  unemployed  people, 
irrespective of their socioeconomic status.5  
 
8. 
Legal  Framework.  The  Government  Law  in  1993  established  the  Ministry  of  Social 
Welfare and Labor (MSWL) and the Social Welfare Law, 1995, established  the  legal  basis  for 
the  current  social  welfare  system.  Amendments  to  the  Social  Welfare  Law  in  1997  and  1998 
instituted  the  management  and  organization  of  an  independent  social  welfare  system.  Further 
amendments  and  revisions  to  the  Social  Welfare  Law  provided  the  legal  basis  for  the  current 
package of social assistance, including the (i) Law on the Social Welfare for Elderly Persons; (ii) 
Law on the Social Security for Persons with Disabilities; and (iii) Law on Allowances to Mothers 
and  Children  and  Monetary  Assistance  to  Mothers,  Children,  and  New  Families  and  Couples. 
These  laws  define  the  current  types  and  coverage  of  social  welfare  pensions,  benefits,  and 
services;  regulate  procedures  for  the  appropriation  and  administration  of  the  social  welfare 
funds; and determine the structure and functions of social welfare institutions.  
 
9. 
An important aspect of the Social Welfare Law is that the eligibility requirements do not 
distinguish between the poor and those with incomes above the poverty line. The amendments 
enacted in January 2008 revised the eligibility requirements for beneficiaries of welfare benefits, 
but they did not include poverty criteria and thus did not address specifically targeting the poor. 
 
10. 
Institutional  Arrangements.  MSWL is responsible for social welfare, social insurance, 
and employment issues at the central level. There are two implementing agencies under MSWL, 
the  State  Social  Insurance  General  Office  (SSIGO)  and  the  Labor  and  Social  Welfare  Office 
(LSWO).  These  agencies  have  representatives  responsible  for  delivering  services  locally. 
Governors  of  all  local  governments 6  are  obliged  by  law  to  undertake  area-specific  social 
protection activities. MSWL is responsible for developing national policies on women, children, 
youths,  the  disabled,  and  the  elderly.  LSWO  is  responsible  for  delivering  social  welfare 

                                                 
3 World  Bank.  2008.  Toward  More  Effective  and  Sustainable  Social  Protection  in  Mongolia:  PEFMR  Dissemination 

Program. (powerpoint presentation) Ulaanbaatar: 3 February 2008. 

4  World Bank. 2009. Mongolia: Consolidating the Gains, Managing Booms and Busts, and Moving to Better Service 

Delivery. A Public Expenditure and Financial Management Review. Washington, DC. 

5  ADB. 2008. Mongolia Country Assistance Program Evaluation: From Transition to Takeoff. Manila. 
6  Governors sign annual performance contracts with the minister of MSWL. 

 

 36      Appendix 2 

assistance  and  services  and  employment  promotion.  The  types  of  social  welfare  assistance 
provided through LSWO include  (i)  in-kind services such as residential facilities for the elderly 
and the disabled and services for the poor, homeless, and children; (ii) discounts and subsidies 
for the elderly, the disabled, and other groups to reduce the costs of housing and health care; 
(iii) short-term cash benefits for pregnancy delivery, child care, families with many children, the 
adoption  of  orphans,  and  infant  care;  and  (iv)  long-term  pensions  for  those  not  eligible  for 
SSIGO assistance.  
 
Public  service  agencies  employ  1,200  social  workers,  798  of  whom  work  for  social 
11. 
welfare agencies, with 510 of them employed at the lowest administrative level of the soum or 
khoroo. Soums and khoroos with large populations recruit social worker assistants to help with 
the  workload.  The  remaining  624  are  employed  by  schools,  law  enforcement  agencies,  and 
hospitals.  About  20%  have  a  social  work  degree.  Recently,  social  welfare  officers7 have  been 
recruited to support social workers in areas with large populations. Livelihood support councils 
have been created to facilitate social welfare outreach and assist in ensuring the identification 
and validation of needy recipients. Although the councils are in place, there are few guidelines 
or resources for staff and little training.   
 
12. 
Recent Reforms and Revisions of Reform. The Government adopted a social security 
sector master plan8 in 2003 as a framework for the long-term development of the sector.9 This 
spelled out the main objectives of reform as (i) rationalizing the number and type of benefits, (ii) 
clarifying  eligibility  criteria  for  benefits  to  improve  the  quality  and  accessibility  of  services,  (iii) 
decentralizing  the  management  of  social  assistance  services,  (iv)  professionalizing  the  social 
welfare  officers  in  charge  of  implementing  social  assistance,  and  (v)  promoting  community 
participation in specific care provider institutions. 
  
13. 
The  2003  master  plan  paved  the  way  for  the  introduction,  in  January  2005,  of  a 
conditional cash transfer that targeted poor households with children aged 0–18. Known as the 
child money program (CMP), it introduced for the first time a PMT that used a set of objective 
indicators  to  identify  the  poor.  The  cash  transfers  were  then  conditioned  on  children  being 
immunized,  living  with  parents,  not  being  engaged  in  intolerable  forms  of  child  labor,  and,  for 
children  aged  8–18,  being  enrolled  in  school.  In  essence,  the  CMP  sought  to  replace  the  old 
system  of  local  authorities'  subjective  assessment  of  poverty,  with  an  objective  test  based  on 
known criteria.  
 
14. 
In July 2006, just 18 months after its introduction, the CMP was universalized under an 
amendment  to  the  Social  Welfare  Law.  Now  all  families  with  children  under  18  years  could 
receive  CMP  benefits.  At  the  same  time,  all  child-related  allowances  other  than  CMP  were 
consolidated  into  a  single  conditional  cash  transfer  of  MNT20,000  per  month.  This  increased 
MSWL expenditures by 61%. In January 2007, the CMP benefit was increased from MNT36,000 
per  child  per  year  to  MNT136,000.  This  was  made  possible  by  the  newly  established 
development  fund  built  up  from  the  windfall  tax  on  copper  and  gold  production.  At  the  same 
time,  two  large  one-time  allowances  were  introduced:  MNT500,000  for  newlyweds  and 
MNT100,000  for  newborns.  Expenditure  shot  up  by  173%  to  equal  11.9%  of  the  budget  and 
5.2%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP).  Within  a  year,  this  swept  aside  early  efforts  to  target 
benefits to poor households, turning a social welfare benefit for the needy into a mechanism for

redistributing wealth generated by mineral exports. In all, the coverage of social welfare benefits 
increased  by  7.6  times  from  2004  to  2007.  The  number  of  beneficiaries  receiving  conditional 
cash benefits increased by 3.6 times from 2006 to 2007.  
 
Challenges.  The  global  economic  downturn  has  severely  constrained  government 
15. 
revenue in Mongolia. The decline in proceeds from minerals created a precarious fiscal situation 
for  the  social  welfare  sector,  which  depended  on  it  to  support  the  CMP,  the  largest  social 
assistance  benefit.  The  main  causes  of  the  deficit  are  identified  as  large  social  transfers  and 
consumption outstripping GDP growth.10 With the fiscal crisis, the Government had to cut back 
on expenditure, reducing the 2009 amended budget for social welfare services by 18.6% from 
the  approved  budget.  Recurrent  expenditures  will  be  reduced  by  20%,  affecting  the 
administration and operation budget of the ministry. But the largest cuts will be made to “goods 
and services.” The following universal programs will be reduced by the proportions indicated: (i) 
the pregnant or feeding mother’s benefit by 12.8%, (ii) the newlywed program by 38%, and (iii) 
the CMP by 33% (a cut of MNT47 billion out of MNT142 billion). 
 
The  across-the-board  cut  in  the  CMP  will  affect  the  poor  disproportionately  as  many 
16. 
depend  almost  entirely  on  these  payments  for  their  daily  subsistence.  However,  the  current 
crisis  environment  provides  an  opportunity  to  reform  the  social  assistance  system  so  that  (i) 
non-poor households can be removed from the list, (ii) benefits can be increased to those who 
remain,  and  (ii)  the  heretofore  unreached  poor  can  be  included.  Rationalizing  the CMP  in  this 
way  can  provide  large  savings,  as  it  is  the  largest  social  benefit  awarded  to  the  public.  The 
International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  estimates  that  converting  the  CMP  into  a  targeted  benefit 
can save MNT61,033 million. Targeting other social benefits more efficiently can save another 
MNT12,206  million.11 With  these  savings,  the  Government  could  raise  benefits  and  improve 
targeting  methodology  and  monitoring.  The  impact  on  the  budget  is  expected  to  be  neutral  or 
possibly positive.  
 
The Government will face both political and technical challenges in reforming the current 
17. 
social welfare system. In the last few years, Mongolians have become accustomed to universal 
benefits so reforms to improve the targeting of social welfare programs will be limited by public 
sensitivities,  popular  expectations,  and  political  demands.  Reluctance  to  undertake  targeting 
can also be attributed to the lack of capacity or knowledge of targeting mechanisms or workable 
models. Although the financial crisis has highlighted the need for targeting, support will need to 
be gained from politicians and wider public. 
 
The  exclusion  from  social  welfare  benefits  of  households  who  have  not  managed  to 
18. 
complete civil registration, for whatever reason, needs to be addressed as a matter of urgency, 
as a large proportion of them are very poor. Several programs are working on this and updating 
the  civil  registration  records.  Any  program  designed  to  address  social  assistance  data 
management will need to consider these developments. 
 
19. 
Currently,  social  assistance  includes  48  programs  and  156  types  of  social  services. 
Many  programs  overlap.  The  absence  of  an  effective,  centrally  operated  management 
information system allows duplication of benefits and other programmatic inefficiencies. Unless

amounted to MNT147.97 billion.

the fragmentation of the social assistance system is addressed, it will be difficult to make it more 
efficient.  Fragmentation  became  part  of  the  policy  dialogue  on  reforming  social  welfare  only 
recently, and resolving it will require advocacy and effective public communication. 
 
C. 

Health  

20. 
Background.  During  the  socialist  era,  Mongolia  established  a  Semashko-style  health 
system,  with  centralized  and  fully  subsidized  state  health  services  provided  through  an 
inefficient  health  care  system  with  a  large  hospital  subsector  but  poorly  developed  primary 
health care (PHC) facilities. After the collapse of the Soviet bloc in the early 1980s, Mongolia’s 
health  care  system  experienced  substantial  regulatory,  structural,  and  financial  changes  to 
address  the  challenges  of  the  new  regime.  The  changes  included  the  emergence  of  private 
health  care  providers,  the  privatization  of  government  facilities,  the  establishment  of  family 
group practices (FGPs), reductions in the number of specialists in favor of a higher number of 
general  practitioners,  and  changes  in  the  salary  system  to  one  based  on  capitation.  More 
diversified health-financing mechanisms were established, including private funding and a social 
health insurance system. 
 
21. 
Institutional Arrangements. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is the Government’s central 
administrative  body  responsible  for  health  policy  formulation,  planning,  coordination  and 
supervision,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation,  as  well  as  for  ensuring  the  implementation  of 
health-related  activities  and  standards  through  its  health  facilities  and  agencies.  MOH  has 
branch offices in each of the 22 local administrative areas (aimags or city health departments).  
 
Health services are provided through public and private facilities at three levels. PHC is 
22. 
fully subsidized from state budget and provided through bag feldshers (village health workers) in 
remote rural areas12 and soum health centers13 (SHCs) and inter-soum hospitals in rural villages 
and FGPs14 in aimag centers and Ulaanbaatar.15 At the secondary level, there are 21 secondary 
level  referral  institutions  in  the  aimag  centers  and  district  general  hospitals.16 At  the  tertiary 
level,  specialty  care  is  provided  through  national  level  institutions  of  general  and  specialized 
centers in Ulaanbaatar and regional diagnostic and treatment centers in three regions.  

 

23.  Mongolia has one doctor per 10,000 residents, which is one of the world's highest ratios, 
higher  than  even  the  developed  country  average.  According  to  2005  health  statistics,  the 
physician-to-nurse  ratio  was  1  to  1.2.  Although  the  health  sector  aims  to  take  a  public  health-
oriented  approach,  the  skills  mix  does  not  reflect  the  main  principles  of  this  policy.  The 
percentage  of  PHC  practitioners  who  work  as  gatekeepers  is  too  low,  and  the  number  of 
specialized  professionals  has  been  growing.  The  hospital  sector  is  still  large  and  inefficient, 
providing low-quality care. 
 
Health  Financing  and  Expenditure.  The  health  sector  is  funded  from  four  main 
24. 
sources.  They  are  general  taxation,  social  health  insurance  fund,  overseas  development 
assistance,  and  out-of-pocket  payments.  In  2002,  the  first  Mongolian  national  health  accounts 
study  estimated  that  71%  of  the  health  expenditure  was  financed  by  government  general

revenue and social health insurance, 15% by private sources,17 13% by overseas development 
assistance,  and  1%  by  community  contributions.  There  is  growing  concern  that  out-of-pocket 
payment has been increasing and becoming a bigger burden on household spending, especially 
for  the  poor.  According  to  a  World  Bank  2009  report,  the  share  of  private  spending  increased 
from  23%  to  37%  between  1998  and  2004,  with  most  of  this  taking  the  form  of  out-of-pocket 
payments  by  2004.  This  has  increasingly  raised  financial  barriers  to  those  seeking  care  and 
greater exposure to financial risk. 
 
Compared with most other low-income countries, Mongolia has historically had relatively 
25. 
high health expenditure, equivalent to about 3.0%–4.5% of GDP and 10–12% of all government 
expenditure. 18  Government  health  expenditure  increased  during  the  years  of  sustained 
economic growth from 2006 to 2008, almost doubling in nominal terms from MNT103.1 billion to 
MNT 229.1 billion. Over the past decade, the Government has accounted for two thirds of health 
expenditure, with just over half going through social health insurance (SHI).  
 
26. 
SHI  was  created  as  an  integral  part  of  the  health  financing  system  in  1994  to  raise 
additional  resources  for  the  health  sector.  It  is  one  of  five  components  of  the  broader  social 
security  system  administered  by  SSIGO.  Employees  and  employers  each  pay  2%  of  salaries, 
for a total of 4%. The Government directly pays the contributions of people who are unable to 
pay  or  otherwise  considered  vulnerable  as  well  as  a  flat  monthly  premium  of  MNT500  for 
children  under  16,  people  whose  only  income  is  a  pension,  people  on  parental  leave,  military 
personnel  on  active  duty,  and  others  as  specified  in  the  Social  Welfare  Law.  Self-employed 
herders,  students  and  unemployed  people  are  responsible  for  their  own  contributions,  paying 
MNT500 per month. The definitions of vulnerability have changed over time and are not based 
on income vulnerability criteria. Over the years, the state-subsidized group has risen from 50% 
of the population to 65%.  

 
27. 
SHI is compulsory in Mongolia and normally provides universal coverage reaching 97% 
in  1996  but  slipping  to  77%  in  2007, 19  mainly  because  of  lower  state  subsidies  for  such 
categories as herders and students and, to some extent, to declining public confidence in health 
insurance benefits. Most SHI expenditure—78% in 2007—has been geared to hospital inpatient 
care provided at the tertiary level.  

 
28. 
The SHI fund is increasingly out of balance. In 2007, employees contributed 76% of total 
SHI  revenue  but  account  for  13%  of  total  expenditure.  State  subsidy  to  SHI  is  25%  of  total 
revenue  but  their  use  of  services  results  to  60%  of  total  expenditure.  This  may  show  social 
solidarity and risk pooling for the sick and needy at the expense of the healthy and well-off, but 
the  poor  quality  of  care  and  increasing  out-of-pocket  payments  at  hospitals,  coupled  with 
bureaucracy and other systemic issues, has created dissatisfaction among the insured.  
 
Performance of the Health Sector. The performance of the health system in Mongolia 
29. 
has  shown  mixed  results.  Life  expectancy  at  birth  is  66  years  only,  slightly  lower  than  in 
Mongolia's East Asian neighbors.20 Mongolia will likely be among the few developing countries 
to achieve the Millennium Development Goals. From 1996 to 2006, the prevalence of measles, 
mumps, and rubella decreased from 170 to 70 per 100,000 live births; the infant mortality rate

fell  from  63.4  to  19.8  per  1,000  live  births;  and  under-5  mortality  fell  from  87.5  to  24.0  per 
1,000.21 However,  recent  years  have  seen  increasing  prevalence  of  cardiovascular  disease, 
cancer, and accidents. Communicable diseases such as tuberculosis and sexually transmitted 
infections remain serious concerns. Tuberculosis prevalence increased from 79 per 100,000 in 
1990 to 155 per 100,000 in 2003 and 185 per 100,000 in 2006.  
 
30.  Mortality  rates  are  five  times  higher  among  the  poorest  20%  of  the  population  than 
among the richest 20%. Tuberculosis and other conditions are strongly associated with poverty, 
as most patients are unemployed and either poor or very poor. Micronutrient malnourishment is 
a  real  concern,  with  one-third  of  children  under-5  suffering  from  rickets,  and  one-half  from 
anemia. An additional concern is that malnutrition remains strongly associated with poverty, with 
the children of poor families three times more likely to suffer from malnourishment and nine out 
of  10  malnourished  children  being  from  poor  rural  families.  These  disparities,  though  not 
unusual  by  international  standards,  point  to  persistent  challenges  in  reaching  vulnerable  and 
high-risk groups with information and services.22 

 
Lower  health  outcomes  for  the  poor  and  disadvantaged  reflect  the  high  cost  of  health 
31. 
services. In theory, the health insurance contributions of the poor are paid by the state, PHC is 
fully subsidized, and the poor are exempt from hospital copayments and official user charges. 
However,  access  for  the  poor  to  inter-soum  hospitals  is  restricted  by  patient  fees,  including 
charges  for  drugs  and  food.  Out-of-pocket  payment  to  all  health  facilities  has  been  a  major 
obstacle to accessing health services, especially for poor and vulnerable groups. 
 
32. 
Official  copayments  in  particular  are  a  major  barrier  for  the  poor.  Patients  are  often 
expected to contribute 30–50% copayment for drugs prescribed by primary care doctors. This is 
especially burdensome to the poor people who use these facilities the most. At the secondary 
level,  10%  copayment  is  expected  for  inpatient  care  and,  at  the  tertiary  level,  15%.  Children 
under  16,  pregnant  women,  women  above  55,  men  above  60  years,  and  invalids  are 
supposedly  exempted  from  official  user  charges  and  their  expenses  are  covered  by  the  state. 
However, in reality this policy is often not applied. As a result, health service usage is some 2.5 
times lower for the poor than for the non-poor, resulting in much lower health outcomes.  
 
33.

34. 
The health sector is challenged to respond effectively respond to the cuts and operate 
efficiently while maintaining health services and protecting the poor during the crisis. In relation 
to this, the key concerns and changes required in the health sector are summarized below. 
 
35. 
Because of the cuts, expenditures on drugs and medical supplies have been reduced by 
20%,  or  MNT5.9  billion.  This  is  a  severe  cut  in  the  context  of  rising  international  prices  and a 
depreciating national currency. This combination of the factors may create further shortages of 
essential  drugs  and  supplies.  Without  appropriate  mechanisms  or  preparedness  nationally  for 
emergencies,  hospitals  are  likely  to  struggle  to  maintain  the  uninterrupted  provision  of  health 
services.  
 
36.  Micronutrient  deficiencies  can  easily  develop  during  times  of  economic hardship,  when 
poorer  households  cut  back  on  food  expenditure,  increasing  the  general  risk  of  infectious 
illness.23 Evidence from other developing countries confirms that rapid increases in food prices 
and food insecurity lead to rapid increases in maternal and child under-nutrition levels. In many 
instances  mothers  act  as  buffers  and  bear  the  consequences  of  qualitative  change  in  dietary 
intake and under-nutrition in an effort to protect their children. The effects are particularly severe 
for babies conceived and weaned during a crisis.24 
 
Although Mongolian society aims, in theory, to  provide free health services to the poor 
37. 
and  disadvantaged,  many  of  the  poor  are  left  out  of  the  system  and  face  difficulty  getting  the 
health services they need. Despite efforts to make SHI universal, it fails to cover almost 20% of 
the population, many of whom are poor. Street children, the unemployed, and the homeless are 
likely  to  be  denied  health  insurance  for  lack  of  civil  registration.  Although  the  state  subsidizes 
the  health  insurance  contribution  of  almost  60%  of  population,  many  of  the  real  poor  are 
excluded  while  many  non-poor  are  included.  This  diminishes  how  effectively  the  policy  can 
protect  the  poor  and  disadvantaged  by  targeting  limited  resources  to  the  needy.  There  is  an 
urgent need to appropriately target the state subsidy to SHI to the real poor.  
 
38. 
There  is  substantial  inefficiency  in  the  health  sector.  Evidence  suggests  that  clinically 
unnecessary hospitalization is common in Mongolia. The share of SHI expenditure for outpatient 
and  PHC,  which  are  recognized  as  the  most  cost-effective  approaches,  continues  to  be  very 
low.  Over  the  years,  SHI  expenditures  for  drug  price  discounts  for  insured  patients  has 
remained  at  about  2%,  without  increasing  even  during  the  years  of  economic  expansion. 
Without effective mechanisms to expand the provision of essential medicines to PHC users, a 
reduction  of  hospitalization  is  unlikely  to  materialize.  In  addition,  there  is  an  urgent  need  to 
improve services of PHC providers to the poor, who are its primary users.

D. 

Education 

39. 
Background.  In  the  mid-1990s,  during  the  transition  period,  school  attendance  in 
Mongolia was poor, many schools were dysfunctional, and teachers were not paid for months.25 
Today,  Mongolia  ranks  high  among  comparator  countries  in  terms  of  school  enrolment  and 
completion.  In  the  2007/2008  school  year,  the  enrollment  rate  for  primary  school  was  92.7%; 
while  the  secondary  school  rate  was  86.8%.  The  completion  rate  of  77%  exceeds  those  of 
Thailand (67%), Viet Nam (56%), and Indonesia (43%). 
 
40. 
These  achievements  follow  a  systematic  restructuring  of  education  institutions  carried 
out  under  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)-funded  Education  Sector  Development  Project. 
This aimed to improve the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of the education system during the 
1990s, the most severe period of transition. A nationwide school mapping study was completed 
in  April  1997,  and  a  plan  was  prepared  for  comprehensive  school  rationalization.  Of  the  171 
schools identified for restructuring, 136, or 80%, were restructured by August 1998 and 35, or 
20%, were restructured by June 2002. This paved the way for new investments in education by 
the state and private sector across the country. 
 
41. 
By  2007/2008  there  were  754  general  education  schools  in  Mongolia  with  a  total  of 
542,505 students. According to Ministry of Education, Culture, and Science (MOECS) statistics, 
23,778  teachers  were  employed  in  general  education  schools,  of  which  22,891  were  fulltime. 
The  average  teacher-to-student  ratio  is  25.5  (footnote  25).  The  shortage  of  teachers  in 
2006/2007 was 479, with the highest number of vacancies in Ulaanbaatar. Of the 754 general 
education schools in 2007/2008, 210 were in Ulaanbaatar and the remainder were in aimags. Of 
the total, 71 schools were primary only, 167 had grades 1–10, and 516 had grades 1–11. Most 
schools  taught  in  Mongolian,  though  in  Bayan-Olgiy  schools  offered  instruction  in  Kazakh. 
Private firms owned 20% of schools. 
 
Challenges. Because of the low population density and nomadic lifestyle of many rural 
42. 
areas,  boarding  schools  play  a  critical  role  in  the  education  system.  A  total  of  495  boarding 
schools  enrolled  44,037  students  in  2007/2008,  or  8%  of  the  student  population,  of  which 
38,255  were  herders’  children.  Overall,  51,118  students  wanted  to  live  in  dormitories,  but 
demand exceeded supply, and many students were forced to live in rented accommodation or 
with  relatives.  The  costs  of  maintaining  small  rural  schools  and  boarding  schools  are  high. 
Maintaining  sufficient  heating  is  critical  and  expensive,  with  15%  of  the  national  education 
budget going to that alone. The extreme winter climate presents challenges for young children. 
Only  half  of  Mongolian  children  receive  any  form  of  early  childhood  education, 26  and  the 
enrollment of children in rural areas and children from herder families in preschool programs is 
particularly low. 
 
Internal  migration  from  rural  to  urban  areas  presents  challenges  to  MOECS.  In  remote 
43. 
rural areas, MOECS has to contend with falling pupil numbers and rising per capita costs, while 
in  urban  areas,  notably  in  Ulaanbaatar,  internal  migration  places  considerable  pressure  on 
school  infrastructure.  Many  schools  now  operate  in  shifts  and  pupil-teacher  ratios  are  on  the 
rise.
