The  Constitution  stipulates  free  basic  education  for  all  children,  but  there  are  many 
44. 
formal and informal costs that are barriers to access. Poverty has a significant impact on school 
attendance. Even prior to the financial crisis, the costs of education paid by parents, including 
textbooks, stationery, school uniforms, and travel to school, were major concerns.  Past surveys 
showed that textbooks were the highest education expenditure for households. For the poorest 
segment of the population, textbook expense account for over 50% of educational expenditures. 
In theory, the Government provides textbooks to 20% of the students who are deemed poor, but 
both coverage and targeting are reported to fall short. Only 9% of students have received free 
textbooks, and there appears to be significant leakage to the non-poor. 
 
45. 
In  addition  to  finding  ways  of  reducing  financial  barriers  to  education,  MOECS  has  to 
consider  how  to  reform  the  curriculum  and  teaching  methods.  In  a  fast-changing  economy, 
children  need  to  be  prepared  to  think  critically  and  creatively.  Unfortunately,  the  Mongolian 
curriculum and teaching methods have not kept up with new demands in the labor market. The 
curriculum  continues  to  be  highly  theoretical  and  focused  on  traditionally  academic  subjects, 
while  teaching  continues  to  be  teacher-centered  rather  than  interactive.  It  encourages 
memorization  rather  than  critical  and  creative  thinking,  and  individual  learning  rather  than 
teamwork.  While  information  and  communication  technology  and  English  language  are  part  of 
the curriculum, teachers are generally not well prepared to teach these subjects. In many cases, 
the teaching of information and communications technology is limited by the low availability of 
computers in schools and inadequate operational budgets.  
 
46. 
The teaching of thinking and behavioral skills needs to be integrated into every aspect of 
the  curriculum  through  discovery-oriented  teaching  methods  that  include  interactive  learning, 
applying  knowledge  to  real-life  problems,  integrating  teamwork  and  peer  tutoring  into  the 
learning  process,  and  inviting  student  input  into  the  structure  and  subject  matter  of  lessons. 
However,  these  methodologies  require  trained  teachers  and  adequate  classroom  facilities  to 
make them effective.  
 
47. 
The  implementation  of  student-centered  learning  will  take  time  and  require  substantial 
investments  in  pre-  and  in-service  training.  In  the  short  run,  teaching  life  skills  as  a  separate 
subject  (e.g.,  health,  citizenship,  or  financial  literacy  education)  may  be  a  practical  option.  To 
improve teaching, teachers need adequate materials and should conduct routine assessments 
of student progress, focusing on their ability to use the knowledge acquired.  
 
48. 
Recent  Reforms.  Recent reforms have seen major shifts in primary education. Before 
2004/2005, Mongolia had a 10-year school system. In that year, an eleventh year was added. In 
the  2008/2009  school  year,  the  system  moved  to  a  12-year  system,  with  school  entry  age 
lowered from 7 to 6. This brought 43,000 6-year-olds into the formal education system in 2008, 
placing significant pressure on the budget. The particular challenges faced in this regard include 
the  need  for  (i)  additional  classroom,  kitchen,  and  dormitory  facilities  appropriate  for  young 
children;  (ii)  training  for  teachers  in  new  skills  and  teaching  methods  for  early  childhood 
education;  (iii)  curriculum  amendment  to  accommodate  6-year-olds;  and  (iv)  new  learning  and 
teaching materials and supplementary reading books. 
 
49. 
New  teaching  methods  have  been  developed  and  tested  in  pilot  (or  model)  schools  in 
collaboration  with  educational  institutes.  The  new  methods  have  been  piloted  for  3  years  by 
MOECS in collaboration with universities and institutes. To provide practice in the new methods, 
a  set  of  24  teachers’  guidebooks  covering  eight  subjects  has  been  developed  and  made 
available to model schools. A joint evaluation conducted by the Japan International Cooperation 
Agency (JICA) and MOECS in March 2009 found the following: (i) the project responded to the 

 

 44      Appendix 2 

priorities of Mongolian education policy and the needs of classroom teachers; (ii) the methods 
enable  children  to  construct  and  acquire  knowledge  by  themselves;  and  (iii)  the  project 
successfully  brought  together  university  teachers,  aimag  or  city  supervisors,  and  teachers  to 
develop  the  teachers’  guidebooks.  It  was  recommended  that  an  action  plan  be  developed 
focusing on how to sustain the project activities and disseminate the new teaching methods. 
 
50. 
Education  and  the  Financial  Crisis.  Until  the  onset  of  the  financial  crisis,  the 
Government  was  able  to  draw  on  its  growing  revenues  to  finance  significant  increases  in 
expenditure in education. Expenditure on education, culture, and science in 2008 was approved 
at MNT386.6 billion, an increase of MNT151.8 billion, or 65%, over 2007. The original budget for 
2009,  approved  by  Parliament  in  2008,  was  MNT432,980  billion,  a  14%  increment  over  2008. 
However, with the onset of the crisis, the budget was amended to MNT386 billion, back to the 
2008  level.  Cuts  in  recurrent  costs  have  primarily  affected  salaries,  wages,  and  related 
expenditures, which have been reduced by 9.1%. Others cuts of such line items as stationery, 
electricity,  heating,  and  transportation  are  by  22.3%.  Budget  cuts  will  require  rephasing  the 
construction of schools, dormitories, and kindergartens. The crisis will severely curtail expansion 
plans for primary schools. In the context of the expenditure requirements brought about by the 
expansion of the school system to 12 years, this has serious implications.  
 
51. 
The ongoing economic crisis and budget cuts threaten the achievement of sector goals. 
The  more  immediate  concerns  affecting  education  during  the  crisis  are  increases  in  (i) 
unemployment (and a consequent decrease in income for parents and guardians); (ii) parents 
unable  to  afford  school  textbooks;  (iii)  school  dropout  rates  and  the  number  of  out-of-school 
children,  especially  in  poor  communities;  (iv)  child  labor  to  compensate  for  falling  household 
incomes  (further  increasing  school  dropout  rates);  and  (v)  urban  migration  (resulting  in  more 
urban  schools  having  to  teach  in  shifts  to  accommodate  rising  numbers  of  students).  The 
provision  of  kindergarten  meals  and  textbooks  and  lunches  for  secondary  school  students  will 
alleviate some financial burden faced by vulnerable families during the crisis.  
 
52. 
Opportunities.  The  Government  of  Mongolia  is  not  alone  in  its  efforts  to  meet  the 
educational challenges described above. Education has received external assistance since the 
early  1990s.  The  Government  of  Japan  is  a  major  bilateral  donor,  providing  grants  for 
renovating  and  upgrading  primary  and  secondary  schools,  strengthening  teacher  training,  and 
information and communication technology in education. ADB continues to support educational 
reforms  through  concessional  loans  and  technical  assistance.  The  Government  has  signed  a 
compact  with  Millennium  Challenge  Corporation,  part  of  which  will  be  devoted  to  developing 
vocational training. Under the Education for All Fast Track Initiative of the World Bank and ADB, 
MOECS is improving access to basic education and enhancing the quality of its services. The 
United  Nations  Children’s  Fund  and  World  Vision  are  active  in  preschool,  primary,  and 
secondary education, while the European Commission and Save the Children United Kingdom 
support  quality  preschool  and  basic  education.  German  technical  cooperation  provides 
assistance for demand-oriented vocational training in cooperation with ADB and the Japan Fund 
for Poverty Reduction.  
 
Overall, external assistance to education sector development has significantly increased 
53. 
in the past few years mostly in the form of grants. To enhance harmonization and coordination 
and improve the efficiency of external assistance, the Government and its development partners 
agreed to establish a sector-wide approach for education. The Education Donors’ Consultative 
Mechanism is now fully operational and co-chaired by ADB and the Government of Japan. The 
Program  will  support  reforms  that  will  bring  improvements  in  teaching  methods  and  pave  the 
way for a project that will provide textbooks to the poor. 

 

 Appendix 2       45 

E. 

Urban Planning  

54. 
General  Background.  Mongolia  has  a  population  of  2.6  million,  40%  of  which  lives  in 
Ulaanbaatar, which continues to experience an accelerating influx of migrants from other parts 
of the country. Annual growth rates between 1998 and 2007 averaged 3.7%, with the population 
of  the  city  growing  from  715,000  to  1,031,000  and  Ulaanbaatar’s  share  of  the  national 
population increasing from 30.5% to 39.1%. The in-migrants have largely settled in ger districts, 
which now house over 60% of the city’s population. 
 
55. 
The residents of the ger districts lack proper housing, access to water, sanitation, roads, 
utilities, and other infrastructure. Ger residents live either in gers (traditional felt tents) or in self-
built  wooden  houses.  While  the  average  household  monthly  income  of  Ulaanbaatar  is 
MNT217,000/household/month,  in  the  ger  districts it  is  MNT180,000/household/month,  or  20% 
less.27 Although incomes of ger households are lower than those of households in other areas 
of  the  city,  there  are  cases  where  ger  households  pay  more  for  water  and  coal  because  of 
limited connection to infrastructure and urban utilities. 
 
56. 
The  Ministry  of  Roads,  Transportation,  Construction  and  Urban  Development 
(MRTCUD)  is  responsible  for  urban  policy  development,  and  the  Municipality  of  Ulaanbaatar 
(MUB)  is  responsible  for  the  hands-on  implementation  of  the  city’s  development. 28 The  Urban 
Planning,  Research,  and  Design  Institute  is  an  independent  public  organization  originally 
established for formulating the 2001 Ulaanbaatar city master plan and is responsible for urban 
planning.   
 
57.  MUB executes its responsibilities through the departments of Environmental Protection, 
Labor  and  Social  Welfare,  Land  Administration,  Police,  Professional  Monitoring,  Public 
Transportation,  Roads  and  Transport,  Traffic  Police,  and  Urban  Development.  The  Urban 
Development  and  Land  Administration  departments  are  responsible  for  redeveloping  and 
improving living standards in ger districts. MUB is responsible for the detailed guidelines that will 
govern  the  day-to-day  work  of  officers  involved  in  the  upgrading.  A  multidisciplinary  working 
group on ger district development has been established to provide oversight. 
 
Legal  Framework.  Major  laws  related  to  urban  planning  are  the  Urban  Development 
58. 
Law,  1988;  Land  Law,  2002;  and  Housing  Law.  The  Urban  Development  Law  established  the 
legal basis for urban development, and amendments in 2008 laid down approval procedures for 
urban development plans and stipulated a zoning system as the basis of effective land use and 
urban  development.  Sub-procedures,  rules  of  enforcement,  and  ordinances  are  still  being 
formulated.  The  Land  Law  and  the  Law  on  Allocation  of  Land  to  Mongolian  Citizens  for 
Ownership, 2002, laid down the basis for the land tenure system. A land ownership allowance of 
700  square  meters  per  household  was  later  amended  to  700  square  meters  per  person, 
accelerating unregulated expansion of the ger area. 
 
59. 
The Housing Law of Mongolia regulates planning and designing issues of housing. One 
of the problems of housing in Ulaanbaatar is that apartment units can be purchased only by the 
higher-middle and high income groups. The master plan study addresses the need to review the 
law  in  view  of  establishing  a  financial  mechanism  to  help  low-income  groups  improve  their 
housing. 

 

                                                 
27 Ministry of Roads, Transportation, Construction, and Urban Development; Municipality of Ulaanbaatar; JICA. 2009. 

Study on City Master Plan and Urban Development Program of Ulaanbaatar City. Ulaanbaatar. 

28 This division of responsibilities is documented in memorandum of understanding between MRTCUD and MUB. 

 

 46      Appendix 2 

Sector  Strategy.  The  Ulaanbaatar  city  master  plan  was  formulated  by  the  Urban 
60. 
Planning, Research, and Design Institute in 2001 and adopted in 2003 as the framework for the 
long-term  development  of  Ulaanbaatar,  targeting  2020.  The  Ulaanbaatar  city  master  plan  had 
not taken into consideration rapid population growth or the rapid expansion of ger districts and 
was  seen  as  inadequate.  MRTCUD  and  MUB  have  conducted,  with  technical  assistance  from 
JICA,  the  Study  on  City  Master  Plan  and  Urban  Development  Program  of  Ulaanbaatar  City to 
formulate  an  updated  city  master  plan  targeting  2030.29 The  master  plan  study  addresses  the 
need  for  establishing  a  legal  system  for  urban  planning  and  development,  a  proper  zoning 
system,  and  participatory  planning  methodologies  to  achieve  the  comprehensive  improvement 
of living conditions in Ulaanbaatar, including the ger districts.   
 
61. 
It  is  essential  that  the  Ulaanbaatar  city  master  plan  be  revised  in  line  with  the  master 
plan  study  and  approved  by  the  Parliament  to  be  effective  for  actual  city  planning  and 
development.  MRTCUD  and  MUB  will  be  responsible  for  setting  up  a  working  group  for  the 
revision of the Ulaanbaatar city master plan and ensuring that funding is secured.  
 
Expenditure.  The  budget  for  MUB  is  prepared  according  to  the  Budget  Law  and  the 
62. 
Public  Sector  Management  and  Finance  Law.  In  2006,  investment  for  projects  in  Ulaanbaatar 
was about MNT20 billion, 58% of which came from the Government of Mongolia and 42% from 
the  local  budget.  While  the  total  revenue  of  MUB  increased  from  MNT38.2  billion  in  2006  to 
MNT65.4  billion  in  2008,  MUB  lacks  financial  resources,  and  it  has  not  been  able  to  invest 
enough in basic urban services or infrastructure development in the ger districts.  
 
63. 
Challenges  for  Urban  Development.  With  an  accelerating  influx  of  migrants  into 
Ulaanbaatar,  the  population  in  ger  areas  increased  by  48%  between  1998  and  2005,  and  the 
residential land area increased by 24% between 1998 and 2006. In addition to problems noted 
above regarding the lack of basic services, the rapid and uncontrolled spread of the city raises 
environmental concerns. Urban sprawl has been mostly to the east and north, toward sources of 
water  that  urban  development  could  contaminate  and,  also,  into  flood-prone  areas,  which  has 
proved problematic. The lack of basic infrastructure such as sewerage and heating systems has 
caused contamination of groundwater and air pollution from burning coal. The situation is further 
exacerbated by the lack of a land management system and mechanism for enforcement. 
 
64.  While Ulaanbaatar faces a number of urban development challenges, Mongolia lacks the 
legal  system  or  organizational  structure  necessary  for  urban  planning  and  development.  Sub-
regulations and administrative procedures for executing the Urban Development Law are not in 
place,  inhibiting  the  actual  implementation  of  development  plans.  There  is  no  mechanism  for 
land-use  control  or  development  permission  linked  to  urban  planning.  Also,  the  administrative 
and  technical  capacity  of  relevant  departments  of  Ulaanbaatar  is  inadequate  to  cope  with  a 
number of urban development challenges.  
 
65.  MRTCUD  and  MUB  have  set  up  working  groups  on  urban  development  law,  land  law, 
and measurement law to address the need to  establish an appropriate legal system for urban 
planning  and  development  in  Ulaanbaatar.  One  of  the  main  issues  that  the  working  group  on 
urban development law deals with is the redevelopment of ger districts. While MUB prepares for 
upgrading ger districts, there is an urgent need for capacity development in the working group, 
so  that  participatory  planning  and  environmental  and  social  safeguards  are  well  incorporated 
into  the  actual  planning  and  implementation  process,  thereby  ensuring  improved  living 
conditions in ger districts.    

                                                 
29 The master plan study commenced in February 2007, and a draft final report was completed in February 2009.  

 

 Appendix 2       47 

 
66. 
According  to  the  ger  districts  development  strategy  approved  by  the  City  Council  of 
Ulaanbaatar, ger districts can be divided into three geographic categories: (i) central ger areas 
with  relatively  good  access  to  public  services;  (ii)  middle  ger  areas,  where  comprehensive 
improvement of living conditions is necessary; and (iii) peri-urban ger areas, where urbanization 
needs  to  be  controlled.  In  the  action  plan,  2009–2010,  formulated  by  MRTCUD  and  MUB, 
detailed planning is scheduled to be conducted for nine middle ger districts. However, the Land 
Administration Department, which is responsible for drawing up detailed plans, lacks capacity in 
land  management  for  urban  redevelopment.  Thus,  capacity  building  targeting  the  Land 
Administration Department is a priority need.

DEVELOPMENT COORDINATION MATRIX 
 
The  development  coordination  matrix  includes  the  policy  reform  areas  and  measures  of  the  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF),  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), and the World Bank (WB) to support the fiscal adjustment necessary 
for Mongolia's economic stabilization program and mitigating the effect of the financial crisis on the poor. ADB and JICA have prepared a joint policy 
matrix.  The  IMF  has  estimated  that  Mongolia  will  need  $284  million  of  external  financing  in  2009  and  $153  million  in  2010.  The  IMF  stand-by 
arrangement will provide $139 million in 2009 and $93 million in 2010. The ADB program support will provide $60 million in 2009 and the Government 
of Japan through JICA will provide $30 million in 2009 and $20 million in 2010. World Bank will provide assistance amounting to $40 million in 2009 
and $20 million in 2010. These combined disbursements will cover most of the financing need, with a gap of $15 million in 2009 and $20 million in 
2010 which the Government envisages covering through assistance from other donors.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
On the strength of high international commodity prices, Mongolia’s gross domestic product (GDP) has grown rapidly for the past 
few  years.  The  country’s  narrowly  based  economy  makes  it  especially  vulnerable  to  commodity  price  fluctuation  and  weather 
shocks. The current global financial crisis has weakened demand for manufactured goods, and this, in turn, has caused copper 
prices to fall by more than 60%. As a result, the budget has come under extraordinary pressure. Nearly 40% of the revenues of 
the Government of Mongolia (the Government) come from mining. This has had immediate and very negative consequences for 
Mongolia’s  fiscal  account,  real  economy,  balance  of  payments,  and  exchange  rate,  as  well  as  the  Government’s  capacity  to 
sustain the provision of universal social transfers.a Mongolia’s poverty rate is a high 35.2%, and inequality has grown markedly 
over the past 5 years. Unless the Government is able to bring about an orderly adjustment to this external shock, the resulting 
social consequences will be severe, threatening to unwind the gains of recent years. The financial crisis exposes vulnerabilities 
in  Government  revenue  sourcing  and  social  assistance  policies.  It  also  presents  an  opportunity  to  address,  through  selected 
policy reforms, changes to promote better targeting of the poor and fiscal sustainability in social assistance. 
 
The Social Sectors Support Program (the Program) will directly contribute to poverty reduction by 
ensuring that social sectors expenditures are maintained during the financial crisis; 
providing  the  foundation  for  reforms  in  social  welfare,  health,  and  education  to  promote  efficiency,  attain  fiscal 
sustainability, and provide assistance to those most in need through targeting methodologies and the creation of an 
inter-sectoral national database of poor households; and 
developing capacity in environmental and social safeguards. 

(i) 
(ii) 

(iii) 

 
To the extent possible, the Program integrates reforms into existing Government programs. Where additional assistance for the 
poor  has  been  identified  as  necessary,  the  Program  has  added  external  funds  from  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction 
(JFPR). This includes expanding micronutrient distribution programs to address the needs of mothers and children and providing 
to the poor a medicard for free access to health services. In addition, technical assistance (TA) will provide capacity building for 
relevant stakeholders in poverty targeting, statistical capacity building, national database creation, and safeguards. Importantly, it 
will  also  help  to  address  political  economy  risks  to  the  reforms  by  ensuring  that  a  consensus-building  and  awareness-raising 
program accompanies the reform process.  
 
The Program directly supports Government efforts to protect spending on the poor and social sectors during the financial crisis. It 
is  coordinated  with  the  range  of  assistance  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  World  Bank,  Japan  International 
Cooperation Agency, United Nations Development Programme, and others that fall under the umbrella of financial crisis support 
from the International Monetary Fund. The Program supports the pillar of inclusive social development in the Country Partnership 
Strategy  and  is  in  line  with  the  emphasis  on  inclusive  economic  growth  in  ADB's  long-term  strategic  framework,  2008-2020 
(Strategy 2020). It directly reflects ADB's response strategy to the global economic crisis of striving to rebalance economies and 
provide support to the poor. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                      Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention (TI-M) 
1.  Key Issues  
Mongolia  is  among  the  29%  of  all  developing  countries  highly  exposed  to  the  poverty-inducing  effects  of  the  crisis,  in  part 
because  of  heavy  Government  reliance  on  volatile  mining  revenues  and  a  high  poverty  rate  of  35.2%  (2007/2008).  What 
progress has been made in reducing poverty is threatened by the economic crisis. Pressure on spending for essential services 
and social  welfare  will have a strong impact on the poor, who rely on affordable access and social assistance as basic coping 
strategies, especially in times of economic stress. 
 
The social impact of the financial crisis must be seen in the context of social and economic change in Mongolia over the past few 
years. Increased migration, urbanization, and changing livelihoods have created newly vulnerable populations. The crisis comes 
directly on the heels of the massive 2008 spikes in inflation, particularly for food items, provoked by the global food crisis. Social 
analysis  carried  out  to  prepare  the  Food  and  Nutrition  Social  Welfare  Program  and  Project  (FNSWPP)  demonstrated  that  the 
poor  were  directly  affected  and  immediately  cut  back  on  the  quality  and  quantity  of  food  they  consumed  and  reduced  or 
eliminated  expenditures  for  health,  education,  transport,  and  energy.  Evidence  from  the  1997  Asian  financial  crisis  clearly 
demonstrates that social sectors are affected if not strongly protected, and that the outcome can be long-term deficits in health 
and education particularly detrimental to the youngest.  
 
The  Mongolia  Country  Poverty  Assessmentb  highlights  several  important  dynamics  of  poverty  that  will  directly  affect  how  the 
financial  crisis  affects  the  poor.  These  include  (i)  rising  inequality  (strong  growth  in  the  economy  has  not  translated  into  faster 
poverty  reduction);  (ii)  worsening  spatial  inequalities  (the  decline  in  the  poverty  rate  in  Ulaanbaatar  is  accompanied  by 

 

 62      Appendix 7 

significantly worsening poverty in soums and the countryside); (iii) reduced social safety nets and insufficient coping mechanisms 
in  rural  and  urban  areas;  (iv)  the  high  reliance  of  the  poor  on  social  welfare  benefits,  especially  the  child  money  program;  (v) 
difficulty in paying for school expenses; (vi) inefficiency in the health insurance system for the poor, and (vii) poor infrastructure 
and access to basic services in urban ger areas. 
 
Beneficiaries of the Program include all citizens of Mongolia for some measures and specifically the poor for others. All citizens 
will  benefit  from  a  social  assistance  system  that  is  fiscally  sustainable.  The  measures  on  health  access  (policy  reform  areas 
[PRA] 3 and 5) and education (PRA 9 and 10) will benefit the entire population, and those on welfare assistance (PRA 2 and 4), 
health  access  (PRA  6  and  7),  education  subsidies  (PRA  8),  and  urban  living  conditions  (PRA  11  and  12)  will  particularly  and 
directly benefit the poor and improve their living standards and access to basic services. The outlined reforms in social welfare 
will directly address Millennium Development Goal (MDG) 1, targets 1 and 3; in health, MDGs 4 and 5; in education, MDG 2; and 
in urban development, MDG 7, targets 3 and 4. 
 
2. Design Features. Direct poverty reduction measures included in the program design include (i) establishing sectoral targeting 
methodologies  and  mechanisms,  an  intersectoral  database  of  poor  households,  and  implementation  and  monitoring 
arrangements; (ii) raising awareness of reforms and establishing a consensus ensuring them; and (iii) the capacity development 
of stakeholders. 
C.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
The impact channels for the policy reforms focus on access for the poor and transfers. Direct and short-term impacts will be the 
maintenance  of  social  expenditures  in  the  Government  budget  and  access  to  benefits  by  the  poor.  Direct  and  medium-term 
impacts  will  be  increased  efficiency,  better  targeting  of  those  most  in  need,  and  capacity  to  monitor  social  welfare  assistance. 
The  major  groups  affected  will  be  all  citizens  for  some  measures,  and  particularly  the  poor,  who  will  be  identified  by  a  proxy 
means test (PMT) and other targeting methodologies for those measures specifically designed to reach them. 
 
The  reforms  will  have  direct  impacts  on  household  social  welfare  benefits,  access  to  social  services,  and,  in  the  longer  term, 
urban  services  in  poor  areas.  The  PMT  will  ensure  proper  identification.  Policy  reforms  will  ensure  the  fiscal  sustainability  of 
social welfare spending. Several of the reforms will have a particular impact on women (e.g., micronutrients and the medicard) 
and directly improve their access to services and better living conditions. 
 
The  policy  reforms  address  poverty  reduction,  pro-poor  growth  and  the  MDGs  by  (i)  reforming  the  social  welfare  assistance 
program to be financially sustainable and to provide targeted assistance to those most in need (MDG 1); (ii) providing access to 
health and nutrition services for all, and in particular the poorest and most vulnerable (MDGs 3 and 4); (iii) providing education to 
poor secondary school students (MDG 2); and (iv) ensuring safe, clean access to basic services in urban areas (MDG 7). 

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings  of  Social  Analysis  Findings from the social analysis  were generated from (i) a review of available reports and 
statistical  data,  (ii)  the  qualitative  participatory  poverty  assessment  and  country  poverty  assessment  (CPA)  carried  out  for  the 
country  partnership  strategy  (CPS);  and  (iii)  a  series  of  rapid  consultations  carried  out  in  urban  and  rural  communities.  Focus 
group discussions included the poor, elderly, and disabled, and key informant interviews focused on stakeholders in the relevant 
sectors. Key findings include the following:  

(i) 

There  has  been  little  poverty  reduction  since  the  last  survey  done  in  2002/2003,  spatial  welfare  differences  have 
become more marked, and inequality has worsened, blunting the effects of poverty reduction. 

(ii)  High inflation from the food crisis in 2008 had a significant impact on the poor and immediate impacts on consumption 

and the access of the poor to services, from which they have not yet recovered. 

(iii)  Focus group discussions revealed that the middle class and the poor both feel that it is pushing them into, or further 
into, poverty. Rising prices for food, falling prices for livestock, limited access to small credit, increasing college tuition 
fees  and  secondary  school  expenses,  downsizing  in  workplaces,  and  worsening  unemployment  are  economic  stress 
factors affecting households.  

(iv)  Coping  strategies  include  pawning  social  assistance  benefits  to  borrow  on  the  future  payments  to  fulfill  immediate 
needs for food, clothing, and access to services; greater reliance on welfare payments for household budgets; limiting 
access to health services and payments for drugs; limiting payments for education; limiting expenses for transport and 
water, etc. in urban ger areas.  

(v)  There is growing public support for targeting social assistance and a real need to address the deficits of the existing 

health insurance scheme to provide benefits where they are most needed. 

(vi)  Poor urban living conditions and services are extremely costly and a priority for residents. 

The  reforms  under  the  Program  help  ensure  that  spending  in  the  social  sectors  is  maintained.  Some  specific  measures  are 
directed particularly at the poor, who will be identified through PMT and geographical targeting.  
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1.  Extensive consultation has been carried out with Government, development partners, and other relevant stakeholders during 
the  preparation  of  the  Program.  In  addition,  the  poverty  and  social  analysis  is  based  on  a  rapid  assessment  with  focus  group 
discussions  and  key  informant  interviews  carried  out  in  rural  soums  and  urban  districts,  the  qualitative  poverty  assessment  of 
February 2009, and the analysis of the 2007–2008 National Statistics Office poverty data compiled for the CPA in April 2009.

3.  Was a C&P plan prepared? 
No consultation and participation plan has been prepared for the Program as the policy measures and tranche conditions mostly 
involve the creation of working groups and ministerial orders. The two health measures that receive external resources from the 
JFPR (micronutrient distribution and the medicard) have consultation and participation activities built into them. TA will support a 
Government advocacy and public awareness program for Parliamentarians, civil society, and the general public. The advocacy 
and  awareness  program  will  focus  on  building  a  consensus  on  social  assistance  targeting  through  a  series  of  workshops  and 
outreach activities that will focus on the (i) benefits of targeting, (ii) need for fiscal sustainability, (iii) mechanics of identification, 
and (iv) grievance mechanisms. 
C.   Gender and Development 
1.    Key  Issues.  Extensive  research  on  previous  financial  crises  has  determined  that  they  have  a  disproportionate  impact  on 
women.  Lost  jobs  in  the  informal  sector,  increased  household  insecurity,  reduced  women's  consumption,  insufficient  social 
protection  spending,  declining  access  to  basic  services,  and  increased  work  burdens  have  all  been  identified  as  gender-
differentiated impacts. The Program directly addresses household insecurity, access to services, and social protection spending. 
Gendered  dimensions  of  poverty  are  evident  in  Mongolia.  Households  headed  by  single  women  are  a  key  indicator  of  poor 
households  and  focus  group  discussions  revealed  that  strategies  for  reducing  personal  consumption  and  increasing  work 
burdens are used, particularly by women, when coping with economic stress. Disparities in health outcomes and primary health 
care  (PHC)  access  affect  men  more  than  women  in  Mongolia.  Women  are  the  primary  users  of  PHC  and  have  better  health 
indicators. The measures will help to ensure basic access for all, and the information, education, and communication component 
will address gender outreach. Girls outnumber boys in schools in every aimag in Ulaanbaatar, and rural areas have dropout rates 
for boys much higher than for girls. The sharp increase in the direct costs of education has widened these disparities, as the cost 
of boys' education is now directly charged to families rather than to the state.

GENDER ACTION PLAN 

 
1. 
Context. Extensive research on previous financial crises has determined that they have 
had a disproportionate impact on women. Lost jobs in the informal sector, increased household 
insecurity,  reduced  women's  consumption,  insufficient  social  protection  spending,  declining 
access  to  basic  services,  and  increased  work  burdens  have  all  been  identified  as  gender-
differentiated  impacts.  The  Social  Sectors  Support  Program  (the  Program)  directly  addresses 
household  insecurity,  access  to  services,  and  social  protection  spending.  Several  of  the 
measures particularly target maintaining maternal and child health. Others will help to address 
longstanding gender disparities, particularly in health and education.   
 
2. 
Preparation:  Preparatory  work  to  identify  and  address  gender  issues  in  the  Program 
was  carried  out  by  desk  review  and  consultations  for  poverty  and  social  assessment  in  urban 
and rural areas. Gender mainstreaming in proxy means test (PMT) development and validation; 
grievance  procedures;  and  information,  education,  and  communication  (IEC)  has  been 
addressed under the Food and Nutrition Social Welfare Program and Project (FNSWPP) gender 
action plan (GAP). A discussion of the gender issues and analysis is included in Supplementary 
Appendix H. 
 
3. 
The  theme  that  links  the  measures  in  the  Program  is  the  targeting  of  poor  households 
through  methodologies  such  as  the  PMT.  This  data-driven  assessment  of  variables  identifies 
households,  not  individuals.  That  said,  recent  poverty  data  highlights  the  vulnerability  of 
households  headed  by  single  women,  and,  through  capacity  building  and  the  development  of 
the  PMT  under  the  FNSWPP  program,  gender  issues  on  vulnerability  will  be  discussed  and 
addressed  as  noted  in  the  GAP  for  that  project.  In  addition,  the  FNSWPP  has  an  extensive 
capacity  development  component  to  work  on  IEC:  about  social  welfare  benefits,  grievance 
mechanisms,  and  the  PMT  validation  process,  all  of  which  has  been  included  with  gender 
mainstreaming activities in that project’s GAP. 
 
4. 
For  the  Program,  the  GAP  outlines  the  gender  impacts  of  the  policy  measures  and 
identifies  specific  actions,  most  of  which  will  be  accomplished  under  the  accompanying 
technical  assistance  (TA),  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  Project  for  micronutrients 
distribution, and the medicard program. It explicitly links to the work being carried out under the 
FNSWPP GAP. The main focus of outputs is the establishment of the national database, which 
will have sex-disaggregated data. Capacity development for gender analysis is included in the 
TA for the National Statistics Office and the team creating the intersectoral database. Capacity 
development for addressing gender dimensions in targeting is addressed in the TA support to 
the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science and the Ministry of Health. IEC for the consensus 
building  component  of  the  TA  and  the  envisioned  outreach  has  gender  mainstreaming  in  its 
terms of reference. Capacity development in environment and resettlement safeguards includes 
attention to gender issues. Specific gender mainstreaming is included in the terms of reference 
for  the  TA  consultants.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Mongolia  Resident  Mission 
(MNRM) consultant will provide guidance to working groups and participate in the ADB review 
missions.
